docs.snippet: LEAD: Muslims with walkie-talkies and solemn stares, some of them armed off-duty correction and police officers, have started to patrol part of the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn in another initiative to rid the community of crime and drug...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Muslims with walkie-talkies and solemn stares, some of them armed off-duty correction and police officers, have started to patrol part of the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn in another initiative to rid the community of crime and drugs, particularly crack.

headline.main: Muslims Start Patrol to Fight Crack in Brooklyn

docs.snippet: LEAD: Following a meeting of the five Central American presidents in Costa Rica last week, the Central American battlefield has shifted north momentarily, to Washington, where the fight is under way over aid to the contras....
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Following a meeting of the five Central American presidents in Costa Rica last week, the Central American battlefield has shifted north momentarily, to Washington, where the fight is under way over aid to the contras.

byline.original: By David E. Bonior; David E. Bonior, Democrat of Michigan, led a House delegation to Central America last week

docs.snippet: LEAD: ''PROMISED LAND'' tries hard to win you over but finally wears you down with its sincerity. Michael Hoffman, the writer and director, seems determined to inject freshness into the old story about graduating seniors who discover life is hard ...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: ''PROMISED LAND'' tries hard to win you over but finally wears you down with its sincerity. Michael Hoffman, the writer and director, seems determined to inject freshness into the old story about graduating seniors who discover life is hard after high school, but he transforms his best ideas and images into bludgeons.

docs.snippet: LEAD: Congress will soon vote on whether to renew military aid to the Nicaraguan democratic resistance. For all its apparent complexity, the issue before Congress and the nation is quite simple....

headline.main: Keep the Pressure On the Sandinistas

byline.original: By Newt Gingrich; Newt Gingrich, a Republican, is a Representative of Georgia

docs.snippet: LEAD: The City Council took a step tonight that it had long avoided, voting to approve a plan for construction of 200 units of low-income housing in the largely white neighborhoods of east and north Yonkers....
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The City Council took a step tonight that it had long avoided, voting to approve a plan for construction of 200 units of low-income housing in the largely white neighborhoods of east and north Yonkers.

headline.main: Housing Plan Approved In Yonkers Council Vote

byline.original: By JAMES FERON, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: President Oscar Arias Sanchez strongly criticized Nicaragua's ruling Sandinista Party on Tuesday night for arresting opposition political leaders. The Costa Rican leader said the arrests were not in accord with the pledges Nicaragua made in ...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: President Oscar Arias Sanchez strongly criticized Nicaragua's ruling Sandinista Party on Tuesday night for arresting opposition political leaders. The Costa Rican leader said the arrests were not in accord with the pledges Nicaragua made in the Central American peace treaty.

headline.main: Arias Is Critical of Nicaragua for Detaining Foes

byline.original: By JAMES LeMOYNE, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: The political leadership of the Nicaraguan rebels agreed today to hold cease-fire talks next week with a delegation of the Managua Government....

headline.main: Contras Agree to Attend Truce Talks

byline.original: By GEORGE VOLSKY, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: Central America's five presidents made a bold decision last weekend. Their plan called for Nicaragua and the United States to take simultaneous steps toward peace - steps neither side liked. With the plan's fate hanging in the balance, the p...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Central America's five presidents made a bold decision last weekend. Their plan called for Nicaragua and the United States to take simultaneous steps toward peace - steps neither side liked. With the plan's fate hanging in the balance, the presidents leaned hard on the Sandinistas to go first. The strategy seems to have succeeded.

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: THE REV. JESSE JACKSON and Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder -the preacher and presidential candidate along with the oddsmaker - met and appeared together on the television news Sunday, looking not so much like an odd couple, not so much like Oscar and Felix or Burns and Allen or Cheech and Chong, but more like opposite sides of a coin, Repentance and

headline.main: Sports of The Times; The Greek and the Preacher

docs.snippet: LEAD: The Reagan Administration will push plans to ask Congress for new military aid for Nicaraguan rebels despite a pledge by the Nicaraguan President, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, to hold direct talks with rebel leaders and suspend a state of emergen...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The Reagan Administration will push plans to ask Congress for new military aid for Nicaraguan rebels despite a pledge by the Nicaraguan President, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, to hold direct talks with rebel leaders and suspend a state of emergency in Nicaragua, senior White House and State Department officials said today.

headline.main: REAGAN WILL SEEK MORE CONTRA AID DESPITE NEW MOVE

byline.original: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to the New York Times
